title: hardhat compile complains about contract size to big even if it's not

body:
First, a clarification: that warning comes from solc, not from hardhat.

I'm not familiar with the internals of `hardhat-contract-sizer`, but I wrote a big contract, and got this warning:

```
Warning: Contract code size is 32029 bytes and exceeds 24576 bytes (a limit introduced in Spurious Dragon). This contract may not be deployable on Mainnet. Consider enabling the optimizer (with a low "runs" value!), turning off revert strings, or using libraries.
```

Running `npx hardhat size-contracts` produces this:

```
 ·------------------------|--------------------------------|--------------------------------·
 |  Solc version: 0.8.17  ·  Optimizer enabled: false      ·  Runs: 200                     │
 ·························|································|·································
 |  Contract Name         ·  Deployed size (KiB) (change)  ·  Initcode size (KiB) (change)  │
 ·························|································|·································
 |  Foo                   ·                31.278 (0.000)  ·                33.189 (0.000)  │
 ·------------------------|--------------------------------|--------------------------------·
```

But according to the generated artifacts, solc is right:

```
❯ jq '(.deployedBytecode[2:] | length) / 2' artifacts/contracts/Foo.sol/Foo.json
32029
```

So... I don't know? @ItsNickBarry do you know what could be going on here?

By default, `hardhat-contract-sizer` outputs values in KiB, because the limit is exactly 24 KiB.  32029 bytes is equal to 31.278 kibibytes, so the output posted by @fvictorio is correct.  I have no idea where the discrepancy posted by @migoldfinger might have come from.
I see, thanks for chiming in! In that case, I think I'm going to close this issue for the time being. I'll re-open if there is some underlying problem in Hardhat that is causing this.
